title: How to Drink Ice Wine

steps.headline: Chill ice wine to 50 to 54° F (10 to 12° C).
steps.description: Ice wine is best when chilled before serving. Store a bottle in your refrigerator for an hour or two before serving it. You could also put it in a bucket with ice to cool it down quickly, but avoid over-chilling it as that will prevent the flavors and aromas from coming through.

steps.headline: Serve ice wine in a white wine glass.
steps.description: White wine glasses are shorter and have a smaller bowl than red wine glasses. They also narrow toward the lip of the glass. A white wine glass is the perfect stemware for showcasing the tantalizing aromas of ice wine. If you don't have white wine glasses, serve ice wine in red wine glasses, champagne flutes, or small cordial glasses. Based in Los Angeles, California, Murphy has collaborated with brands such as Equinox, Buzzfeed, WeWork, and Stage & Table, to name a few. Murphy possesses her WSET (Wine & Spirit Education Trust) Level 3 Advanced Certification. Murphy Perng			Certified Wine Consultant				Did You Know? Many dessert wines are sweetened through the fermentation process or by adding additional juices near the end of the winemaking process. However, ice wine has a natural sweetness—it's produced in areas where the grapes freeze during cold weather, which concentrates the sweetness and flavor.

steps.headline: Pour 1.5 to 2 oz (50 to 60 mL) per person.
steps.description: Because ice wine is intensely sweet, a little goes a long way. Only fill the white wine glasses about a quarter full. Put the ice wine bottle in the fridge after pouring it to keep it cold for the next round.

steps.headline: Drink ice wine within two weeks of opening the bottle.
steps.description: After opening a bottle of ice wine, re-cork it and put it in the refrigerator. Ice wine has a high sugar content, so it stays fresher longer than many other wines as long as it's sealed and refrigerated.

steps.headline: Drink ice wine for dessert.
steps.description: Enjoy a small glass of ice wine as a dessert beverage after a nice meal. The sweetness makes for the perfect nightcap.

steps.headline: Make ice wine slushies.
steps.description: Put 6 oz (200 mL) of ice wine in a blender and add 8-10 ice cubes. Blend the drink until it has the consistency of a slushie. Pour it into a chilled glass and serve. This drink is perfect for hot summer days!

steps.headline: Create an ice wine cocktail.
steps.description: Combine 1 ½ oz (50 mL) of sparkling ice wine, 1 ½ oz (50 mL) of vodka, and 1 ½ oz (50 mL) of lime juice in a cocktail shaker. Shake it with crushed ice then serve it in a martini glass with a lime garnish.

steps.headline: Make an ice wine Manhattan.
steps.description: Put 1 ½ oz (50 mL) of rye whiskey, 1 oz (30 mL) of ice wine, and several ice cubes in a cocktail shaker. Shake it, then pour the drink into a rock glass. Garnish the glass with a slice of orange and some frozen cranberries.

steps.headline: Add a splash of ice wine to sparkling drinks.
steps.description: Pour a dash of ice wine in your favorite sparkling drink or cocktail, such as a bellini or a mimosa, to add sweetness and complexity. You could also use ice wine in a wine spritzer.

steps.headline: Pair ice wine with strongly flavored foods.
steps.description:
Ice wine perfectly complements strongly flavored foods. The sweetness and acidity of the ice wine will pair nicely with strong tastes.Examples of strongly-flavored foods include: 
Aged blue cheese
Wasabi peas
Black olive tapenade
Foie gras

steps.headline: Serve ice wine with rich seafood.
steps.description: Crab cakes, lobster, or scallops sauteed in butter would be a perfect pairing for ice wine. This sugary wine will complement the flavor of the seafood while it's sour undertones balance out the richness.

steps.headline: Choose spicy foods to pair with ice wine.
steps.description: Spicy dishes, including curries, cajun dishes, and spicy Asian cuisine, pair well with ice wine. The cool and sweet fruitiness of ice wine is a perfect balance to the spice and heat.

steps.headline: Enjoy a glass of ice wine with a semi-sweet dessert.
steps.description: Ice wine pairs well with dessert items like dark chocolate. Choose a dessert that is not intensely sweet, such as poached pears, cheesecake, or shortbread cookies. Based in Los Angeles, California, Murphy has collaborated with brands such as Equinox, Buzzfeed, WeWork, and Stage & Table, to name a few. Murphy possesses her WSET (Wine & Spirit Education Trust) Level 3 Advanced Certification. Murphy Perng			Certified Wine Consultant				You can also go with a very sweet dessert, if you prefer. When you're drinking ice wine, try pairing it with something at least as sweet as the wine, if not sweeter. For instance, you might serve ice wine with a piece of pecan pie or a caramelized dessert at the end of a nice meal.
